awd_titl_txt: Bridge to the Doctorate: Greater Philadelphia Region Cohort XV Project - Drexel University
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines:  African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders.  The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on Ph.D. matriculation and completion.  BD programs implemented in the nation's institutions of higher education contribute to addressing one of the objectives in NSF's 2014-2018 Strategic Plan, namely to "integrate education and research to support development of a diverse STEM workforce with cutting-edge capabilities."  The vision of this grant is to provide a national model to produce underrepresented scientists and engineers with doctoral degrees in STEM.

Drexel University (DU) serves as host of a Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) project within the Greater Philadelphia Region Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation.  The DU BD activity employs a multifaceted model that integrates research, education, and mentoring to address challenges underrepresented students face in doctoral programs.  As such this project seeks to (1) recruit twelve students into Ph.D. degree programs at Drexel University; (2) develop each student in their science or engineering discipline through individual and group mentorship and graduate professional development activities; (3) engage and retain these students through the completion of the Ph.D., and (4) monitor all student progress through Ph.D. completion into the professoriate and/or industry.  The program components are executed via academic coursework for scientific and technical competency that prepares BD students for the doctoral degree qualifying and candidacy examinations; substantive cutting-edge laboratory research experiences beginning in the first-year to expose fellows to research that can form the basis for their doctoral dissertation; professional development experiences such as workshops, seminars and/or conferences to help students to develop the ancillary skills needed for personal and professional success; facilitated interaction with faculty and peers to fully integrate students into research groups; opportunities for students to present their research nationally and/or internationally to promote their engagement with the larger scientific and technical community; and opportunities for student reflection, and the development of coping skills to contextualize the pressures and challenges associated with graduate study.

por.por_cntn:
Drexel University, as a representative of the Greater Philadelphia Region Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (Philadelphia AMP), received funding from the National Science Foundation to host a Bridge to the Doctorate Cohort XV project to expand and intensify the consortium's on-going efforts to substantially increase the number of students from underrepresented minority groups, mainly African American, Hispanic and Native American students, entering graduate study in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), attaining doctoral degrees, and moving into the professoriate and/or industry. The Philadelphia AMP represents a diverse alliance of nine institutions consisting of public and private, 2- and 4-year research and non-research, Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and majority institutions. 

The goals of Philadelphia AMP's Bridge to the Doctorate (Cohort XV) project were to: (1) recruit twelve (12) students into PhD degree programs at Drexel University; (2) develop each student in their science or engineering discipline through individual and group mentorship and graduate professional development activities; (3) engage and retain these students through the completion of the PhD, and (4) monitor all student progress through PhD completion into the professoriate and/or industry. Following the establishment of its new Graduate College as part of its Responsibility Center Management (RCM) institutional restructuring, and its highly successful Drexel University BTD Cohort III, VIII and XI projects, it was the Alliance's intent to admit the new cohort of BTD Cohort XV students directly into PhD programs.

Historically, of the thirteen (13) BTD fellows recruited for PhD program participation: a) three (3) fellows decided to change to MS programs which made them ineligible from continuing to receive the BTD fellowship based on Drexel's BTD Cohort XV project's PhD enrollment requirement, b) one (1) fellow was dismissed for poor academic progress, c) two (2) fellows withdrew due to unforeseen personal and/or family circumstances, d) two (2) fellows opted to discontinue their doctoral studies for personal reasons to pursue career opportunities, and e) five (5) BTD fellows were retained and also attained a cumulative GPA of 3.68 or above.   To date, of the latter retained fellows: a) one (1) fellow successfully defended her dissertation and was awarded her PhD degree in Information Science in September 2022, b) two (2) fellows have attained PhD candidacy in Microbiology & Immunology, and Biomedical Engineering, respectively, and c) two (2) fellows are expected to attain their PhD candidacy in December 2022 in Mechanical Engineering & Mechanics, and Biomedical Engineering, respectively.

Upon review, it is our belief that the latter change in BTD practice to only recruit students directly into doctoral programs resulting from the institutional RCM restructuring, along with other unforeseen circumstances beyond our control, have regrettably negatively impacted the recruitment, as well as the retention rate of the BTD Cohort XV project before, as well as after the COVID-19 pandemic outbreak. Despite the unanticipated BTD Cohort XV project outcomes which were inconsistent with Drexel University's previous record of success in achieving the objectives of the Bridge to the Doctorate program under its previously hosted BTD Cohort III, VIII and XI projects with regards to PhD productivity and scholarship,  the BTD Cohort XV project findings have helped to bring additional institutional awareness, as well as aided in the facilitation of structural, operational, and policy changes designed to broaden and enhance the recruitment and retention of not only underrepresented STEM students, but that will better prepare both faculty and all students for more successful graduate outcomes under the institution's newly revised organizational operations. Several of the lessons learned include the need to expand the diversity of the STEM graduate pipeline and to improve the utility of skill-building and environmental assessment instruments to gauge student development and satisfaction. These action items and associated plans of action positioned BTD as an auspicious program through which best practices could be piloted and potentially expanded to wider graduate audiences to optimize recruitment and retention initiatives; the latter also included the development of an institutionalized structure to ensure availability of mentorship for all diverse graduate/doctoral populations to overcome gaps/shortages that may exist in any one unit, department, school or college.

The implementation of mechanisms to actively promote the success of diverse student populations continues to be a priority among University administration and faculty.  The BTD Cohort XV project created additional opportunities to pilot, implement and influence best practices. One of the objectives of Drexel's BTD Steering Committee was to document those practices and innovate in the areas of training and development [for faculty and students] to yield increasingly positive gains in recruitment and persistence among diverse STEM student communities.  The newly established Graduate College Diversity Council has also created an opportunity to expand the reach of efforts undertaken through BTD to impact a broader group beyond the STEM disciplinary areas.
